A series of hybrid catalysts with different catalytic bed dispositions (layer bed and simple random mixture) of Cu- 
ZnO-Al 2O3 and SAPO-34 have been adopted and evaluated in syngas conversion into light C2-C4 hydrocarbons. 
An effect of the proximity between the two solids on the CO hydrogenation activity was demonstrated. A sphere 
contact quantification model was developed to estimate the concentration of contact between them for any 
simple random mixture. Comparing the evolution of gain of CO conversion (or hydrocarbon yield) with the 
theoretical results, it was shown that the density of contact was identified as the key factor for the catalytic 
performances (contact-activity relationship). Finally, the knowledge of the contact morphology, determined by 
FEG-SEM, allowed proposing the NH3-TPD as method characterizing the concentration of contact.   
1.Introduction 
Light (C2-C4) hydrocarbons are important chemical building blocks 
for a variety of useful derivatives in the petrochemical and chemical 
industries [1,2] . They are presently produced worldwide in huge 
amounts mostly by steam cracking of naphta which is highly 
energy-consuming process. C2-C4 hydrocarbons synthesis from syngas 
(a mixture of CO and H2) is attractive since renewable carbon resources 
(biomass, wastes, CO2) are expected to gradually replace fossil fuels [3]. 
Fischer-Tropsch (FT) synthesis is the traditional process of converting 
syngas to hydrocarbons [4]. However, the FT process is limited by the 
Anderson�Schultz�Flory (ASF) distribution and contain a small yield of 
C2-C4 hydrocarbons [5,6] . 
A two-step process including methanol synthesis (Reaction 1) fol-
lowed by methanol-to-olefins (MTO, Reaction 2) process is commer -
cially available to produce light hydrocarbons but development of a 
more energetically and costly-efficient direct process is needed [7].

The advantage of the single-step process is the achievement of both reactions (Reactions 1 and 2) in one reactor in order to simplify the 
process route and equipment [4]. This process is possible using a 
so-called hybrid or bifunctional catalyst. The bifunctional catalyst cor-
responds to a physical mixture of methanol synthesis catalyst (Cu-Z -
nO-Al 2O3) and zeotype (SAPO-34), can lead to the formation of light 
hydrocarbons from syngas via methanol as reactional intermediate [4,8, 
9]. The main advantage of the single-step process is the elimination of 
the restriction of methanol synthesis by the thermodynamic equilibrium 
shift (drain-off mechanism) [10]. It can be assumed therefore that the 
proximity between methanol synthesis catalyst and SAPO-34 (where the 
methanol is converted) plays a significant role in the catalytic perfor -
mances (high. CO conversion) and in the hydrocarbon selectivity [9]. 
In the present work, we investigated the activity of hybrid catalyst 
for the CO hydrogenation into hydrocarbons (HC) as a function con-
centration of contact between methanol synthesis catalyst (M1) and 
SAPO-34 (M2). In order to evaluate the effect of the proximity between 
M1 and M2, different catalytic bed dispositions (layer bed, denoted LB, 
and simple random mixture, denoted SRM) of both components have 
been adopted. Using a similar methodology as previously described [11, 
12], we built contact –reactivity relationship on the basis of catalytic 
observations. The results led us to formulate hypotheses concerning the 
morphology of the contacts, as well as the development of a

2.Materials and methods 
2.1. Materials 
2.1.1. Methanol synthesis catalyst 
A commercially available methanol synthesis copper-based catalyst 
(M1) was used. This is a material developed by Johnson Matthey and 
sold by Alfa Aesar (a Johnson Matthey company) in the form of 
5.4mm×3.6mm pellets. These pellets were crushed and sized to 
160�100 µm (in this form, the apparent density of the M1 (denoted 
ρM1) material is equal to 1.23 gcm-3 and the radius of the M1 material is 
rM1 =65.0 µm). 
2.1.2. SAPO-34 
A SAPO-34 zeolite (M2) in the form of fine powder was purchased 
from ACS Material. It was pelletized, crushed and sized to 160�100 µm 
(in this form, the apparent density of the M2 (denoted ρM2) material is 
equal to 0.94 gcm-3 and the radius of the M2 material is rM2 =65.0 µm). 
2.1.3. Hybrid catalysts 
2.1.3.1. Layer bed arrangements. The layer bed arrangements (denoted 
xLB(y), where x and y represent the number of layers and the number of 
contacts, in terms of contact section between M1 and M2, respectively) 
are presented in the Table S1. The same amount of M1 (160�100 µm) 
and M2 (160�100 µm) reference materials was used for each of LB arrangement. The differences between the LB arrangements are the 
number of alternating layers between M1 and M2, resulting a change in 
the number of contacts (see Table S1). 
2.1.3.2. Simple random mixture arrangements. The simple random 
mixture arrangements (denoted SRM(x), where x represents the M2 
proportion) were prepared by simple mixing M1 (160�100 µm) and M2 
(160�100 µm) reference materials with different weight ratios. The 
characteristics of SRM arrangements are presented in the Table S2.

3.2. Catalytic performances 
3.2.1. M1+M2 arrangements 
3.2.1.1. Catalytic performances with layered bed (LB) arrangements. The 
impact of the contact concentration between M1 and M2 is investigated 
using the different layered bed arrangements present in the Table S1. 
The performance of M1 and different catalytic layered bed arrangements 
at 15h of reaction is shown in Fig. 3 (the evolution of the CO conversion 
and the product selectivities versus the time on stream is presented in 
Fig. S4). The M1 catalyzed the conversion of syngas to CH4, CO2 and 
hydrocarbons (denoted HC, mostly C2H6) with selectivities of approxi -
mately 45%, 40% and 10%, respectively. The CO conversion (denoted 
XCO) is approximately 7% (with WHSV=10L.h-1.g-1, see Fig. 3a); and methanol (denoted MeOH) and dimethylether (denoted DME) traces are 
observed (Fig. 3b). These results clearly indicate that, under our 
experimental conditions, M1 favors the methanation and Water Gas 
Shift (WGS) reactions at the expense of methanol synthesis reaction, 
which is also in agreement with the thermodynamic equilibrium data 
presented in Table S5. No activity is observed for M2 alone (not pre-
sented here). When the M2 catalyst is associated with the M1 catalyst, 
without contact (2LB(0) arrangement, where M1 and M2 are separated 
from each other by a 1cm thick layer of SiC), the CO conversion (Fig. 3a) 
and the CH4 and CO2 selectivities (Fig. 3b) are not changed compared to 
the test with the M1 catalyst alone. However, the disappearance of 
MeOH and DME is observed in favor of hydrocarbons. When the both 
catalysts are in contact (2LB(1), 4LB(3), 6LB(5), 8LB(7) and 10LB(9) 
arrangements), an increase in CO conversion (Fig. 3a) and HC selectivity 
(mostly C3H8) and a decrease in CH4 selectivity are observed (Fig. 3b, 
the CO2 selectivity is constant for all the catalytic tests). This phenom -
enon is amplified with the increase in the number of contacts between 
M1 and M2 layers. The formation of hydrocarbons is explained by the 
transformation of methanol intermediate formed over M1 into hydro -
carbons over M2 acid sites, thus inhibiting the CO methanation and/or 
the hydrogenation of MeOH into CH4 over M1[13]. The intimacy be-
tween both materials leads to a strong increase in the proportion of 
paraffins relative to olefins (see the P/O ratio in Fig. 3b), indicating the 
hydrogenation of the olefins. Hydrogen spillover (from M1 to M2) 
and/or olefins spillover (from M2 to M1) and/or the hydrogenation of 
olefins by crossing through a layer of M1 would probably explain this 
[14,15] .

3.2.1.2. Catalytic performances with simple random mixture (SRM) 
arrangements. In order to improve the CO conversion, different simple 
random mixtures of M1 and M2 were made. Different compositions of 
these SRM arrangements were used to vary the contact concentration

The impact of the composition of the SRM arrangement at 15h of

reduction) as well as in mixtures of different compositions, according 
with the methodology used in our previous study to determine the 
concentration of number of contacts between two materials [12]. With 
the statistical and geometric approach of the Dodds model [16,17] , it is 
possible to easily describe the texture of a 3D polydisperse random 
mixture. The Dodds model assumes that each particle constituting the 
polydisperse mixture is in contact with all its neighbors. This basic hy-
pothesis allows to divide the space into tetrahedral subunits ijkl (i, j, k 
and l representing the indices of the species constituting the four vertices 
of a tetrahedron), containing a part of vacuum and each vertex being the 
center of a given particle. A binary random mixture (composed of 2 
families of type 1 and 2 particles, representing M1 and M2, respectively 
for this study) has 5 types of tetrahedral subunits (1111, 1112, 1122, 
1222, and 2222, Fig. 5b). These different tetrahedral subunits are 
geometrically fully characterized with the angles a, b and c at the 
summit i, the spherical angles α, β and γ and the area AT of the spherical 
triangle (ABC) [18]. The geometry of such a tetrahedral subunit is 
completely described by the radii of the four spheres forming it (ri, rj, rk 
et rj). By knowing the particles radii and their distributions in number, it 
is possible to determine coordination numbers, porosity, and distribu -
tion of the different contact types in the polydisperse mixture. In the 
spirit of the Dodds model, model calculations were performed. A 
mathematical model was developed in order to determine the concen -
tration of number of contacts between M1–M1, M2–M2, and M1–M2 
(denoted [NC11], [NC22], and [NC12] and expressed in number of 
contacts per gram of catalyst) for any composition of the SRM catalyst 
(see Fig. 5c, all the details of the proposed model are presented in the 
supporting information in the section “Description of the contact 
model ”). 
In order to have a representative view of the impact of the M1-M2 contacts in the XCOgain , we compared the evolution of the normalized 
concentration of number of contacts between M1–M2 with the 
normalized XCOgain as a function of the M2 proportion in the catalyst 
(Fig. 5d). It clearly appears that the obtained volcano curve for the 
concentration of number of contacts between M1 and M2 with a 
maximum at 50% M2 is identical to the one obtained for the normalized 
XCOgain . This result validates the contact –reactivity relationship 
hypothesis. 
3.4. Reduced SRM arrangement structure and morphology 
We observed that the CO conversion is dramatically affected by the 
SRM catalyst composition, and therefore by the amount of M1-M2 
contacts present in the hybrid materials. We investigated the structure 
and textural parameters for the best CO conversion catalyst (SRM(0.50)) 
to understand the nature of M1-M2 contacts. The XRD diffractogram at 
the fresh plotted in Fig. S6a is a linear combination of the M1 and M2 
ones. After reduction, it corresponds to a combination of the diffracto -
gram of reduced M1 and to the one of SAPO-34 for which the peaks are 
slightly shifted to the low angles (Fig. S6b). This shift could be due to 
cationic exchange within the zeotype. [19,20] The morphology of the 
reduced SRM(0.50) catalyst obtained by FEG-SEM measurements is 
presented in Fig. 6 (see also Fig. S7 in supporting Information for the 
complete EDX mapping analysis). The reduced catalyst behaves like a 
dense packing of randomly distributed binary grains with grain sizes 
similar to those of the fresh hybrid catalyst (Fig. 6a), which agrees with 
the starting point of our theoretical model (Fig. 5a). In order to differ -
entiate the nature of each catalyst grain, a mapping of the main char-
acteristic elements of M1 and M2 (Cu (in red) and P (in yellow), 
respectively) was carried out (Fig. 6b). It can be seen that, after the 
reduction, this granular mixture includes not only conventional contacts 
between the grains of M1 and M2 (as one might expect), but also a

3.5. Characterization of the M1-M2 contacts 
The quantity of interphases between M1 and M2 can be determined, 
indirectly, using the properties of a Cu exchanged SAPO-34 synthesis 
method, generally used for the selective catalytic reduction with 
ammonia (NH 3-SCR) [19]. This method, named solid-state ion-exchange 
(SSIE), consists in mixing copper oxide with SAPO-34 and heating it at low temperature (T<250◦C) under an atmosphere of NH3, which leads 
to the diffusion of metal ions in the zeolite [19]. The mobility of Cu is 
proposed to be related to the formation of complexes [Cu(I)(NH 3)x]+
(x≥2). Indeed, these linear complexes have a diameter similar to that of 
an NH3 molecule, thus allowing these species to easily penetrate into the 
porous system of the zeolite and thus to improve the Cu exchange. One 
can thus easily imagine that if one carries out this method with our 
materials (LB and SRM arrangements), the mobility of Cu should in-
crease with the concentration of contact between M1 and M2. The use of 
NH3 temperature programmed desorption (NH 3-TPD) on our materials 
allows not only to perform the SSIE process during the NH3 adsorption 
step, but also to indirectly quantify the amount of Cu exchanged in M2 
(and therefore a representation of M1-M2 contact concentration).

some cations to the framework [28,29] ) and a high temperature (HT) 
peak (>400◦C, attributed to NH3 adsorbed on Brønsted acid sites i.e. 
formation of NH4+[20–24]). NH3-TPD of reduced SRM(0.50) followed 
by DRIFT spectroscopy (Fig. S8) confirmed the presence of Lewis acid 
sites (bands at 3385 –3335, 3275, 1622, 1274 and 1219 cm-1) and 
Brønsted acid sites (3270, 1490 –1450 cm-1) as well as NH3 adsorbed on 
Cu+sites on SAPO-34 (3184 cm-1). A detailed attribution is provided in 
the supporting information .

different masses of M1 and M2 alone. From these new profiles, it was

4.Conclusion 
In order to evaluate the effect of the proximity between Cu-ZnO- 
Al2O3 and SAPO-34 in the conversion of CO into hydrocarbons, different 
catalytic bed dispositions (LB and SRM) of both components have been 
adopted. When the SAPO-34 catalyst was associated with the Cu-ZnO- 
Al2O3 catalyst (LB arrangement), without contact, CO conversion has 
not changed compared to the test with the M1 catalyst alone. However, 
the disappearance of methanol and DME was observed in favor of hy-
drocarbons (with a significant selectivity toward CH4 and CO2). When 
both catalysts were in contact (LB arrangement), an increase of CO 
conversion and HC selectivity and a decrease of CH4 selectivity were 
observed. This phenomenon is amplified with the increase of the contact 
concentration. In order to improve the CO conversion, different SRM of 
Cu-ZnO-Al 2O3 and SAPO-34 were made. The impact of the composition 
of the SRM hybrid catalyst was investigated and shown a volcano-like 
profile for CO conversion as a function of M2 content in the catalyst. 
To elucidate the effect of composition on CO conversion a mathematical 
model for Cu-ZnO-Al 2O3 and SAPO-34 contact quantification, based on a 
geometrical and statistical approach allowing the textural description of 
a random polydisperse medium, was developed. The experimental re-
sults were compared with theoretical calculations. A direct correlation 
was found between theory and experiment. The density of contact be-
tween Cu-ZnO-Al 2O3 and SAPO-34 was identified as the key factor for 
the catalytic performances (contact-activity relationships). Finally, the 
knowledge of the contact morphology, determined by FEG-SEM, 
allowed proposing the NH3-TPD as the concentration of contact char-
acterization method.

The rising concerns about global warming and imbalance in the carbon cycle urge rapid development of
efﬁcient CO 2conversion processes. We report an exceptionally productive process for the synthesis of
methanol via continuous catalytic hydrogenation of CO 2under high-pressure conditions (up to
360 bar) over co-precipitated Cu/ZnO/Al 2O3catalysts. Outstanding one-pass CO 2conversion (>95%) and
methanol selectivity (>98%) were achieved under an optimized range of reaction conditions. At a very
high GHSV of 182,000 h/C01over a commercial methanol synthesis catalyst, the process delivers
7:7gMeOH g/C01
cath/C01, which is by far the highest yield value reported to date, at the expense of lowered
CO2conversion (65.8%) and methanol selectivity (77.3%). Using a mixed bed consisting of the Cu/ZnO/
Al2O3and H-ZSM-5 catalysts, one-step conversion of CO 2into dimethyl ether with remarkable selectivity
(89%) was attained at the equivalent or higher CO 2conversion level. Furthermore, we demonstrate that
the efﬂuent stream of methanol, rich in H 2and water, from the methanol synthesis reactor can be directly
fed to a reactor containing the H-ZSM-5 catalyst for selective production of alkane (85%) or alkene (42%),
depending on the operating pressure of the secondary reactor.

1. Introduction
The global warming, mainly sourced from the human induced
emission of CO 2, is one of the major environmental threats we
are facing in the 21st century. In the past few decades, there has
been growing scientiﬁc consensus to devise the strategy for CO 2
capture, ﬁxation, and recycling technologies to level off the atmo-spheric CO
2concentration. Nature has its own CO 2ﬁxation process
which is extraordinarily selective in converting CO 2into organic
compounds. However, natural chemical transformation of CO 2is
not simply fast enough to cope with the increasing CO 2emission
rate of the industrialized world. Chemical transformation of CO 2
is not only about mitigating the global warming; rather it is aboutrecycling of the carbon, irreversibly relocated in the form of CO
2
from the ground by burning fossil fuels such as coal, oil, and natu-
ral gas. In the light of the ﬁnite availability of fossil fuels, the pro-
duction of commercially valuable chemicals and fuels from CO 2is a
promising strategy to simultaneously tackle the two major prob-
lems of the century, namely the global warming and fossil fuel
depletion, for sustainable development. Among others, heteroge-
neous catalytic hydrogenation of CO 2bears a strong potential totreat large amount of CO 2in a short time, rendering it an important
mean for CO 2conversion.
Methanol (MeOH) can be synthesized from CO 2hydrogenation
and is one of the most celebrated and widely suggested alterna-
tives for chemical energy carrier [1,2] . It is an excellent fuel and
a key starting material of the important industrial reactions. The
use of methanol in fuel cells directly or indirectly as the source
of hydrogen by a reforming reaction is well documented. Actively
investigated hydrogen production by photocatalytic or electrocat-
alytic water splitting powered by renewable (e.g. solar and wind)
energies can be regarded as future sources of hydrogen for CO 2
hydrogenation [3,4] . In addition, fundamental chemical products
like oleﬁns can be produced via a methanol-to-oleﬁn (MTO) pro-
cess [5]and various organic compounds like dimethyl ether
(DME), that is, a potential substitute of diesel oil for its better com-bustion performance [6], can be produced from methanol. The
commercially practiced processes of methanol synthesis from CO
and CO
2are operated at relatively low one-pass conversions and
require separation and/or recycling of unconverted reactants to
attain high conversions. Currently, the commercial methanol
synthesis processes are operated typically at about 50–100 bar
using copper- and zinc-based catalysts [7]. Lowering the reaction
pressure is generally favoured because of the general perception
of increased energy demands at high-pressure operation. However,
a recent report on energetic aspects of CO 2hydrogenation to

The ﬁrst high-pressure methanol synthesis process was com-
mercialized by BASF in 1923, operated at pressure of 250–
350 bar with a mixture of syngas with CO 2as reactants [9]. The
use of high pressure was necessary due to thermodynamics; de-
crease in temperature and increase in reaction pressure should fa-

processes are operated at lower reaction pressures of ca. 50–

tive Cu–Zn-based catalysts [10]. Related to CO 2hydrogenation,
Ipatieff and Monroe reported high-pressure study up to 412 bar
over Cu/Al 2O3catalysts in a ﬁxed bed reactor, which showed
remarkable selectivity to methanol and high conversion of CO 2
[11]. However, in their study, the gas hourly space velocity (GHSV),
indicative of the productivity of the reaction, was very low (ca.
1000 h/C01) to make the process practically viable.
Herein, we report high-pressure (up to 360 bar) CO 2hydrogena-
tion to methanol over co-precipitated Cu/ZnO/Al 2O3catalysts at
high GHSV (>10,000 h/C01). Under speciﬁc reaction conditions with
conventional methanol synthesis catalysts, we will show that one
can achieve close-to-full one-pass conversion of CO 2to methanol.
Furthermore, DME and hydrocarbons production from methanol
can be directly incorporated or combined with the methanol syn-
thesis process, outlining the high ﬂexibility and versatility of the
reported CO 2hydrogenation process.
2. Experimental
2.1. Materials
Copper nitrate hexahydrate ( P98%, Alfa Aesar), zinc nitrate
hexahydrate (98%, Sigma–Aldrich), aluminium nitrate nonahydrate
(P98%, Fluka), potassium hydroxide ( P85%, Sigma–Aldrich), c-
Al2O3(Bimodal, Alfa Aesar) and NH 4-ZSM-5 (SiO 2/Al2O3= 50/1, Alfa
Aesar) were used as received. Deionized water was used for cata-
lyst synthesis. A commercial methanol synthesis catalyst was pur-
chased from Alfa Aesar (Product ID: 45776). Liquid CO 2
(>99.9993%) and 10% Ar in H 2(>99.999% for Ar or H 2, prior to mix-
ing) were purchased from Linde.
2.2. Catalyst synthesis
For the synthesis of Cu/ZnO/Al 2O3, aqueous solutions of copper
nitrate hexahydrate (0.2 M), zinc nitrate hexahydrate (0.2 M) and
aluminium nitrate nonahydrate (0.2 M) with potassium hydroxide
(0.5 M) were slowly added together, in a round-bottom ﬂask to
precipitate the corresponding hydroxides. During the precipitation,
the round-bottom ﬂask was heated at 80 /C176C under constant stir-
ring, and the pH of the solution with precipitate was maintained
between 9.5 and 10.5. The precipitate was aged for 48 h, ﬁltered
and washed with water until the pH of the washed solution
reached the value of 7.5. Then, the sample was dried at 100 /C176C
overnight, crushed and calcined in air at 400 /C176C for 4 h to yield
Cu/ZnO/Al 2O3(I). Following the same synthesis procedure, twomore catalysts, Cu/ZnO/Al 2O3(II) and Cu/Al 2O3, were prepared
using different compositions of precursor solutions. H-ZSM-5 was
prepared by calcination of NH 4-ZSM-5 in air at 400 /C176C for 4 h. An-
other Cu/Al 2O3(18/82 wt%) catalyst was prepared by the incipient
wetness impregnation method. The preparation method and cata-
lyst properties are described elsewhere [12]. Prior to charging the
catalysts into reactor, they were pelletized, crushed and sieved a
size of 100–300 lm. Elemental composition, Cu surface area, CuO
crystallite size and BET surface area of the synthesized and com-
mercial catalysts are listed in Table S1 (Supplementary material ).
2.3. Catalytic testing
CO2hydrogenation reaction was performed in the microreac-
tion set-up and tubular reactors (ID: 1.74 mm, OD: 3.17 mm) were
used throughout. Details of the set-up and method of product anal-
ysis are described elsewhere [12]. For methanol synthesis, 170 mg
of Cu/ZnO/Al 2O3(I) was used. In the study of very low to high
GHSVs using the commercial catalyst, 1000, 85 or 42.5 mg of the
catalyst was used for the catalytic tests in the range of 425,
10,000–40,000 or 81,000–182,000 h/C01, respectively.
For the synthesis of DME, H-ZSM-5 (150 mg) was mixed with
Cu/ZnO/Al 2O3(II) (170 mg) and charged into one reactor or the
two catalysts were charged separately into two reactors connected
in series.
For hydrocarbon synthesis, H-ZSM-5 (170 mg) was charged into
a reactor connected in series after that containing Cu/ZnO/Al 2O3
(II) for methanol synthesis. The temperature of the secondary reac-tor containing H-ZSM-5 was controlled independently from the
ﬁrst one. For alkane synthesis, the reactor with H-ZSM-5 wasplaced before the back pressure regulator, thus kept at the same
pressure as the ﬁrst one ( Fig. S8 ). While in alkene synthesis, the
secondary reactor was located after the back pressure regulator
(Fig. S9 ) and kept at the atmospheric pressure. It should be noted
that GHSVs for the combined processes (DME and hydrocarbon
syntheses) were calculated based on the amount of the methanol
synthesis catalyst in the reactor.
For the above three reactions, argon was used as an internal
standard for gas chromatography (GC) analysis and product selec-
tivity was calculated taking only carbon-containing products into
account.

4. Conclusion
The catalytic system described in this work provides an efﬁcient
and highly productive processing strategy for CO 2conversion at a
single step. The high-pressure approach using a conventional Cu/
ZnO/Al 2O3methanol synthesis catalyst under speciﬁc reaction con-
ditions for CO 2hydrogenation remarkably boosted methanol selec-
tivity and productivity by (i) the high H 2partial pressure to
enhance the reaction rate and (ii) thermodynamically favoured
high CO 2conversion and methanol selectivity at high pressure.
The preliminary experiments with the commercial catalyst showed
extraordinary high methanol productivity at very high GHSVs, pos-
sibly justifying the capital and manufacturing costs of high-pres-
sure processes. Negligible pressure drops under the examined
GHSVs are the advantage of compressive reactants at high pres-
sure. The consumed hydrogen was exclusively utilized for metha-
nol formation at increased hydrogen partial pressure, thereby
increasing the efﬁciency of the process towards methanol synthe-
sis by suppressing chemical and thermal energy consumption for
RWGS reaction. Moreover, the excess of hydrogen remaining instream present under the optimal reaction condition reported in
this work can be fed directly to another identical or multiples of
high-pressure reactors with possible reduction in their sizes, so
that compression of hydrogen may only require at initial stage
whereas methanol productivity would be multiples of connected
reactors. In such conﬁgurations, the recycling of H
2can be mini-
mized or potentially omitted.
One-step transformation of CO 2to DME by the co-presence of
the H-ZSM-5 catalyst showed remarkable ability of this process
without lowering the CO 2conversion level. Also, the methanol-,
water- and H 2-rich stream can be directly fed to the reactor con-
taining the H-ZSM-5 catalyst and good selectivity to alkane or al-
kene was attained, instigating further development of CO 2to
oleﬁns and/or gasoline processes via one-step hydrogenation. The
CO2transformation approach presented in this study may allowthe convenient operation of small scale yet highly productive
plants for CO 2hydrogenation at sites where CO 2is captured and
stored.
